Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Eyewitness memory in children and adolescents with Autism Spectrum Disorder

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past decade, the prevalence of children diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) has dramatically risen from 1 in 150 to 1 in 68. Such increases in prevalence foretell greater involvement of these children in the legal system. Yet science-based interview protocols for obtaining accurate eyewitness reports, available for typically developing children, do not exist for children with ASD. This study examines the effectiveness of two current child forensic interview protocols at eliciting accurate and complete eyewitness statements from (verbal) youth with and without ASD, and determines individual difference predictors of eyewitness memory performance.

Children, 9- to 18-years-old, with and without ASD, will participate in a documented event and will later be questioned with one of two forensic interview protocols. Analyses will examine components of protocols that aid or impede accurate reports. This study addresses debates about disability, competence, and law. Moreover, it will expand theoretical understanding of ASD (e.g., self-development theory) for scientists and provide needed empirical information for legal professionals and fact finders to facilitate reaching the truth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past decade, the prevalence rate of individuals diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder has increased more than 50% and currently stands at 1 in 59. Corresponding increases exist in occurrence of autism in youth interacting with legal professionals within the justice system. The Bureau of Justice Statistics estimates that those with disabilities, including Autism Spectrum Disorder, are 2.5 times more likely to be victim of a crime than those without disabilities.

Eyewitness accounts collected from victims, with and without disabilities, help initiate legal action and aid in obtaining justice.  Of concern is whether eyewitness accounts from youth with autism are as accurate as eyewitness accounts from typically developing youth and whether current interview strategies support accuracy and reduce error.

Memory for events (?episodic memory?) is reportedly diminished in those with autism. Compared to individuals without the disorder, individuals with autism produce episodic memory narratives that contain fewer details and causal statements, lack social content (in favor of nonsocial content), and are missing themes that represent the gist of the event. These episodic memory differences are likely due to cognitive and social communication difficulties associated with autistic symptoms. Given that individuals with autism may interpret, remember, and report eyewitness events differently than do typically developed individuals, a special approach to interviewing may be needed.

However, much of what is known scientifically about memory in autism comes from testing adults. The present study compared episodic memory reports of typically developing children and teenagers with those of high-functioning (i.e., verbal) children and teenagers who suffer from autism. We also examined the effectiveness of two forensic interview protocols that are often used to collect eyewitness accounts from victims. The two protocols selected rely on different interviewing strategies: The Cognitive Interview (CI) uses self-guiding memory techniques, such as sketching, that minimize social interaction during eyewitness accounts, whereas the 10-Step Protocol uses a back-and-forth, open-ended questioning style (?You mentioned X.  Tell me more about X.?) that may reduce cognitive efforts of self-guided memory retrieval attempts. Thus, we studied youth with and without autism to address the usefulness of the two interview protocols given that this is an understudied research area and given the urgency posed by the increasing prevalence rates of autism in youth.

Tested separately, all youth (9- to 18- years-old) first experienced a staged, semi-distressing event involving four actors who were assistants involved with the study. Then, three weeks later, each youth returned and reported as much information as they could remember, using one of the protocol methods. After their eyewitness narratives were completed, they then responded to a series of questions, some of which were suggestive questions or asserted false information (e.g., ?What spilled all over the floor when you were in the room??, when in fact nothing had spilled). Additional information about youth?s cognitive, social, and language abilities were collected using parent questionnaires. The main interests of the study were whether the two diagnostic groups (i.e., autistic compared to typically developing youth) varied in memory performance in their narratives and responses to questions as well as examining whether existing eyewitness protocols are effective.

Results indicated that narratives provided by autistic compared to non-autistic youth contained fewer details; however, this varied by youth age and interview protocol. Compared to young typically developing youth (≤ 14 years old), age-matched youth with autism provided fewer details in their narratives when the CI was implemented. For older youth (> 14 years old), individuals with autism, compared to those without the disorder, provided fewer details in their narratives when the 10-Step Interview was used. Autistic youth in these groups reported fewer details about people, actions, and objects/setting, with the greatest differences observed in reporting of action details. Of importance, no diagnostic group differences emerged for memory performance assessed via questions. That is, all youth answered questions about people, actions, and objects with similar accuracy rates, regardless of whether the questions contained false information or not. Autistic youth?s memory performance was positively associated with cognitive abilities (i.e., flexibly thinking), particularly in those who received the CI. Better ability to adapt ones? language to meet social demands was strongly associated with greater memory accuracy.

This study offers early evidence that existing protocols may not be optimal for youth with autism, yet for different reasons that may be linked to age. Younger autistic youth may benefit more from methods that emphasize narrative assistance, whereas older autistic youth may benefit more from methods that minimize social interaction. Ways to modify protocols further should be identified so as to maximize eyewitness accuracy when a victim has autism by reducing language and social interaction burdens. Autistic individuals can report accurate information under certain conditions and respond to questions accurately. Additional research is needed to identify such conditions that will assist legal professionals in collecting accurate eyewitness reports from child victims with autism.
